category.text: $course$/Default for CST415/498 SE3: Inception and Elaboration (Fall 2010)

questiontext.text: In your requirements elicitation practice session involving group techniques, you tried both brainstorming and the affinity process. For the second activity (the affinity/sticky-note process), list the final set of requirements RANKED HIGHEST TO LOWEST in terms of priority. Explain the reasons for your chosen rankings.

In your requirements elicitation practice session involving group techniques, you tried both brainstorming and the affinity process. For the first activity (brainstorming), list the final set of requirements RANKED HIGHEST TO LOWEST in terms of priority. Explain the reasons for your chosen rankings.

In your requirements elicitation practice session involving group techniques, you tried both brainstorming and the affinity process. In a short essay, please explain the following: What are the major differences between the brainstorming and the affinity processes as covered in the lab? When might you use brainstorming? When might you use the affinity process? Explain and provide evidence for your response. Which techniques are you more likely to use in your project and why?

In your requirements elicitation interview exercise, you took turns with your partner interviewing another pair of students, and getting interviewed by them in turn. Discuss how similar or different the requirements you gathered from each source turned out to be (is there evidence for your answer?). How did you and your partner try to resolve any discrepancies in the 2nd round of interviews? How well did your efforts turn out and why do you feel that way?

Indicate how your team has employed interviewing and group elicitation techniques in the context of your project. Be specific as to when, where, and who was involved. Describe the extent to which the process you used on the project matched the process described in class (or in your textbook). Describe the benefits and drawbacks to techniques you have employed. If you have not employed any of the 3 techniques, indicate that as well and describe why you have not employed the technique.
Match the technical method with the phrase that best characterizes it

subquestion.text: a combination of natural and programming languages intended for understanding by both programmers and non-programmers
eliminates ambiguity by elaborating the various conditions of the system and its processing of inputs
a better representation of nested conditional structures when dealing with multiple inputs
a modern-day version of a flowchart
a visual depiction of the structure and relationships between data elements

questiontext.text: Match the workshop preparation activity to the description of the concept

subquestion.text: Communicate the benefits of the workshop approach to members of the team
Identify the right people who can contribute to the process or whose needs will be met

answer.text: Ensuring the Participation of the Right Stakeholders

subquestion.text: "Get their minds right"
This activity is important because this person plays a pivotal role in the workshop's success
Approaching preparation with a high degree of professionalism conveys its importance to participants.

questiontext.text: Match the description with idea reduction steps

subquestion.text: Visit each generated idea looking for quick agreement by the group that the idea is OK.
Putting related ideas together and naming them.
Providing a 1-sentence description of the idea
Voting, Categorizing, Ranking, etc.

questiontext.text: Match the description with the type of storyboard

subquestion.text: Non-interactive presentation that a human walks the stakeholder through
An automated description of system behavior in typical scenarios
Simulations or related forms that allow the user to experience the system in a realistic way

questiontext.text: Match the Characteristics of a good SRS with its description

subquestion.text: every requirement stated in the SRS is one that the software shall meet
every requirement has only one interpretation
every requirement has an identifier to indicate the importance or stability of the requirement
every requirement has a finite, cost-effective process exists that can check the software product meets the requirement
the style and structure of the SRS are such that any changes can be made easily, completely, and consistently while retaining that same structure and style
the origin of each requirement is clear and the SRS facilitates referencing in future development or documentations

questiontext.text: Match the best practice to the requirements engineering process phase in which that practice is best applied:

subquestion.text: Get extensive user involvement
Prioritize requirements
Inspect requirements specifications
Manage requirements changes

questiontext.text: Match the step in the problem analysis process to the example of an activity to do in that step.

subquestion.text: Write the problem down and see if everyone agrees

answer.text: Gain Agreement on the Problem Definition

subquestion.text: Chart the problem and possible explanations in a fishbone diagram
Ask questions about who will use, buy, maintain, approve, etc. the finished system
Determine the inputs and output of a system, and/or the types of users (actors) and their interactions with the system.

Having a checklist of questions to ask will help discover these nonfunctional requirements. These requirements are defined as things the system cannot do, or restrictions on how it much be developed, deployed, and/or operated.

questiontext.text: The "User and Developer" problem is a fundamental communication problem. Match the communication problem with the recommended possible solution.

subquestion.text: Users are unable to communicate what they want

answer.text: Try more than one elicitation technique

subquestion.text: Users think they know what they want until someone gives it to them
The solution provider thinks they know what is needed more than the users do
The situation is politically charged

answer.text: Understand and deal with it, these situations are real life
Confront the situation and bring the problem to light

questiontext.text: Match the software process phase with the closest description

subquestion.text: Coding the project
Identifying what, in the customer's mind, the software should do. Expressing this in the customer's vocabulary.
Understanding the scope of what is to be done, and translating it to technical vocabulary
Activities that help identify defects in a system or application
Activities that transition the software system or application from a development environment to the operational environment
Updating the software to correct defects or provide new features after the software is operational

questiontext.text: Match the software process lifecycle model with its closest description

subquestion.text: A linear model where the phase transitions are well-defined
Emphasizes risk management as a key activity in the software process
Delivers software repeatedly in smaller increments
Emphasizes people and continuous feedback over defined process control

questiontext.text: Match the activity description with the Use case building step.

subquestion.text: Who uses the system? What other systems use this system?
What will the system be used for?

answer.text: Identify Use Cases and write a brief description

subquestion.text: Analyze each use case and determine what actors interact with it

answer.text: Identify Actor to Use Case relationships

subquestion.text: write down the basic flow and then the alternative flows
specify all alternative flows and pre/post conditions

questiontext.text: Orthogonality, or when there is little correlation between the {1:MC:=requirements~design~implementation} and the {2:MC:requirements~=design} or implementation

Requirements workshops are designed to {1:MULTICHOICE:bore you to death~=encourage consensus~promote diverse discussion} on the requirements and to {2:MULTICHOICE:move slowly~explore all options~=gain rapid agreement} on a plan of action in a {3:MULTICHOICE:way that makes everyone feel happy~=very short time~methodical way}.
Brainstorming has two phases, idea {1:SA:=generation} and idea {2:SA:=reduction}

The authors give some advice about storyboarding. They say to storyboard {1:MULTICHOICE:late~cautiously~=early~quickly}, storyboard {2:MULTICHOICE:infrequently~=often~quickly~anywhere}, and storyboard {3:MULTICHOICE:=on every project that has innovative content~on only the most important projects~with online tools}
A use case describes sequences of {1:SHORTANSWER:=actions} a system performs that yield an {2:SHORTANSWER:=observable result} of value to a particular {3:SHORTANSWER:=actor}.
UML specifies icons for use case diagrams. The icon for a use case is a(n) {1:MULTICHOICE:stick figure~=oval~rectangle} and the icon for an actor is a(n) {2:MULTICHOICE:=stick figure~oval~rectangle}.
Your textbook suggests using the "technical methods" approach when

answer.text: the description of the requirements is too complex for natural language
you cannot afford to have the specification misunderstood
your colleagues are easily impressed by math notations
you are looking to impress your professors
you need to get a better estimate of costs

questiontext.text: We use architecture to

answer.text: Think and work on pieces of the system

questiontext.text: The purpose of modeling is

answer.text: simplify to the point that the system is not represented
ensure proper examination of the implementation details

questiontext.text: What are sources for the orthogonality problem?

answer.text: The two spaces use different languages
Some requirements have more to deal with process structure than code structure
Some requirements are implemented across multiple interacting system elements
design is optimized for reasons other than traceability
requirements are done by business analysts, coders do the design and implementation

questiontext.text: A use case realization is part of the
Benefits of running a requirements workshop include

answer.text: Gets stakeholders and developers to agree
They come from a single source of information
Stakeholders can only contribute in areas they know about
improves morale as everyone would rather be in a meeting

questiontext.text: Which of the below is a benefit of brainstorming?

answer.text: Allows participants to build off each other's ideas
Generates a lot of ideas in a short time
A number of possible solutions are discovered
Lets the most aggressive people put forward the most ideas

questiontext.text: To make sure people do not get shy and tentative about volunteering ideas, following this rule is especially important.

answer.text: Generate as many ideas as possible

questiontext.text: Benefits of storyboarding include

answer.text: You can generate code from them

questiontext.text: Of the 8 quality characteristics of an SRS, which can apply to individual requirements instead of applying to the SRS as a whole?
An SRS should not

answer.text: define all of the software requirements
limit the range of valid software designs
impose additional constraints on the software

questiontext.text: The SRS should not include information about which of the following

answer.text: Describing flow of information or control

questiontext.text: Prototyping is a useful requirements quality activity because

answer.text: customers are more likely to review a prototype and provide feedback than an SRS
it may introduce new questions, giving implicit feedback on the state of the elicitation process
it leads to reduced change during development
you can reuse it to build the production software
developers are always happier when writing code

questiontext.text: An SRS should address:

answer.text: Design constraints imposed on an implementation

questiontext.text: Weigers suggests which of the following as quality techniques?

answer.text: Write test cases before you write any code

questiontext.text: Which of the following characteristics of individual requirements does Weigers list as necessary that DO NOT APPEAR in the list of SRS characteristics in the IEEE 830 specification?
Weigers' suggests which of the following as tips for writing better requirements:

answer.text: Read a requirement from the developer's perspective
Watch out for multiple requirements aggregated into a single requirement
Write requirements at a consistent level of detail
Write requirements using structured natural language
Capture requirements as user stories to avoid incorrect narratives

questiontext.text: Weigers characteristics of a quality SRS itself include
Which of the following can determine correctness of the requirements?
At various points, the article suggests which of the following are problems to deal with in the requirements engineering process (choose all that apply):

answer.text: an attitude that code is the only tangible form of progress
a failure to understand the return on investment (ROI) of good requirements engineering
a lack of respect for the customer

questiontext.text: Three levels of requirements, according to the author, are
The elicitation best practice that suggests it is just as important to understand how well the system will perform its functions as it is to describe what the system will do is
According to your text book chapter 5, problem analysis is first and foremost a _____
According to your textbook chapter 5, a problem is the difference between the _______ and the _______
According to the 1995 ESPITI study, the least important problem in delivering software was

Examine the pyramid figure on page 10 and the read carefully the middle paragraph on page 12. The paragraph says that Snyder and Shumate found on Hughes projects, that 74% of requirements errors were found and fixed in requirements analysis, 11% leaked into (and were presumably fixed in) design, and 4% made it out to maintenance. Your question: If there are 100 total requirements defects on a Hughes project, and the unit cost of finding a fixing a requirements defect in the requirements analysis phse is $1, then how much total $$$ is spent on finding and fixing requirement defects in the requirements analysis, design, and maintenance phases respectively?
The 1994 Standish Group report also suggest some common root causes for problems on software projects. These common root causes included:
The 1994 Standish Group report, which is a widely cited industry study, indicates which of the following about the state of the software industry?

answer.text: Almost 1/3 of software projects get canceled before they complete
Over 1/2 of software projects cost almost twice their original estimates
$130B goes to canceled over over-budget projects
Outsourcing is responsible for a 20% cost savings in software projects since 1985
The Web has resulted in a 35% cost of development increase since 1990

questiontext.text: A customer for our software product or service may come in which of the following forms:

answer.text: an external entity buying our product
someone asking us to develop custom software for hire
works at the same organization as us
a professor who requires we do it

questiontext.text: Before we conceptualize or form our first solution to the problem, we want to ________ the customer in order to understand the real problems.

answer.text: review the statement of work with

questiontext.text: Some of the confounding (problematic) factors to conducting interviews to elicit requirements include

answer.text: The "User and Developer" syndrome from chapter 8
We bring our biases to the table, including experience in solving the same problem type before
It can be hard to schedule time with the stakeholder
Interviews can have awkward pauses of silence

questiontext.text: Some tips for conducting a successful interview include

answer.text: Prepare - write down the questions to ask beforehand
Research the background of the stakeholder and company before the interview
Refer to your preparation notes during the interview
Make sure you arrange to have good food there

questiontext.text:
"Undiscovered ruins" is another name for a classic problem called "feature creep." This is a situation where new features seem to creep into the software even after the requirements have been established.
What step of problem analysis (Chapter 5) can be done better to resolve the "Undiscovered Ruins" problem?

answer.text: Gain agreement on the problem definition

questiontext.text: According to your textbook, users' reaction to the first time they see the implemented application is typically "Yes, but..." because:

answer.text: it is human nature; they haven't seen it before
they did not understand what it meant when the solution was described to them earlier
it is not what they expected
they changed their minds about it from before
they are trying to get more for their money by dragging you along

questiontext.text: What is one thing you can do to combat the "Yes but..." syndrome?

answer.text: Show the user working software earlier and get feedback
Stand your ground and say, "no new features"
Ask the customer for more money than you know s/he is willing to spend
Ignore the demands and move on
Do not show the customer the solution until the last day, and provide no warranty for your software

questiontext.text: When a stakeholder is asked about what they want in a new system or application, s/he usually responds with a description of a
This says nothing about what will be in the software being constructed.
Why is it important to understand whether the stakeholder is describing to you a business need or the description of a software feature?

answer.text: The need defines the real business problem; the feature is the stakeholders filter of what s/he thinks is needed to solve the problem
You charge for your software based on how many features you implement, not how many needs you address
Features can be tracked, needs cannot
If it is a feature then you should also know what requirements it is tied to

questiontext.text: Which of the following are part of almost every software process lifecycle model?
What are some of the drawbacks of the Spiral Model

answer.text: Difficult to execute on small projects
Moves very aggressively through the lifecycle
You can get lost in where you are in the process

questiontext.text: What are some of the benefits of the Spiral model? Choose all that apply.

answer.text: Is easy to understand and execute

questiontext.text: What are some of the drawbacks of the Waterfall process?

answer.text: Each phase must be perfect before moving on
Inflexible in the face of change

questiontext.text: What are some of the benefits of using a Waterfall process?

answer.text: Complete requirements reduces defects and saves time later
Ensures good documentation of the project

questiontext.text: Every use case has 4 mandatory parts:
Which of the following are benefits to the use case approach?

answer.text: Forces developers to consider the perspective of the user
Provide a mechanism for ordering requirements
They carry over into the testing process
Provide context for the system; how it meets its objectives
Engages the users in the requirements development process
If you do use cases you do not have to do anything else
They are in vogue (popular) so using them makes you look good

questiontext.text: Primary internal stakeholders for a Vision document are
Requirements engineering is primarily a _______________ activity, not a technical activity.
The ratio of the cost of finding and fixing a defect in the requirements phase versus finding it in the maintenance phase is ____ to 1.
The incremental part of the "Iterative and Incremental" software lifecycle process refers to developing the software in
The iterative part of the "Iterative and Incremental" software lifecycle process refers to developing the software in
The Vision documentis supposed to capture the __________ of the envisioned software system.
A purposeful attempt to do a 1:1 mapping from requirements to code leads to a object-oriented design

I certify that my responses on this quiz reflect my individual thought and activity; I have not collaborated on my answers with anyone inside our outside of class (including on the Internet) in any way. I understand if that I answer false to this question Dr. Gary will not score my quiz and I will receive a zero. I understand that if I answer true to this question but in fact have collaborated with someone, I am subject to failure in the course and discipline in accordance with the ASU ethics policies.
No matter how much you work on requirements, they will never be perfect.
Poor requirements can lead to excellent software
Context-free questions are meant to start directing the stakeholder toward the solution you have in mind.
When conducting the interview, you should stop the stakeholder from rambling on and on, and instead cut them off and go on to the next question to make sure you make the best use of the time.
Questionnaires should not replace interviews, and in fact should be done after interviews have taken place
An actor is a restricted subset of the system's stakeholders consisting only of its human end users.
